summary: This is a legal filing by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys (Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C.) in the civil case Giuffre v. Maxwell. It is a reply brief supporting Maxwell's objections to unsealing various sealed discovery materials. The document argues for maintaining the seal on many documents, citing protective orders, privacy interests of non-parties, potential for abuse and defamation, and the low presumption of public access for discovery dispute materials. This is a court order from Judge Kenneth A. Marra denying motions by Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4 to join as petitioners in a CVRA action against the government regarding the Jeffrey Epstein non-prosecution agreement. The order also denies Alan Dershowitz's motion to intervene and strikes detailed allegations about non-parties from the record.

connections.description: Menninger is lead defense attorney filing this reply brief on behalf of client Ghislaine Maxwell.
Maxwell is described as Epstein's associate, with the case involving allegations she committed crimes with him.
Mentioned as parties in related civil litigation (Giuffre v. Dershowitz), with Dershowitz asserting Maxwell's credibility is at issue.
McCawley is opposing counsel for the plaintiff, advocating for unsealing materials against Maxwell's objections.
Judge Marra struck allegations from Jane Doe 3's pleadings in a Florida case, describing them as 'lurid' and 'unnecessary'.
Jane Doe 3 alleges she was sexually abused and trafficked by Jeffrey Epstein.
Jane Doe 4 alleges she was sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein.
Dershowitz moved to intervene to strike allegations made against him in filings related to Jane Doe 3's claims.
Both are original petitioners in the CVRA action, represented by the same counsel.
Both moved to join the CVRA action as petitioners, represented by the same counsel as Jane Doe 1 and 2.

events.title: Filing of Maxwell's Reply Brief
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's legal team files a reply brief in support of her objections to unsealing sealed discovery materials in the civil case.

events.title: Deposition of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The deposition of Ghislaine Maxwell is referenced, where she was asked numerous personal and allegedly irrelevant questions.

events.title: Judge Marra's Order in Doe v. United States
events.description: Judge Marra denies motions to join Jane Doe 3 and 4 and strikes certain pleadings containing 'lurid' allegations about being 'sexually trafficked to several high-profile non-party individuals'.

events.title: Deadline for Objections to Unsealing
events.description: The court's protocol set a deadline for parties to object to unsealing sealed materials.

events.title: Motion to Join CVRA Action
events.description: Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4 moved to join as petitioners in the CVRA action via Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 21.

events.title: Court Denies Motions to Join and Intervene
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra issued an order denying the Rule 21 and Rule 15 motions by Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4, and denying Alan Dershowitz's motion to intervene as moot.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York
Denver, CO (Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C. office)
Ft. Lauderdale, FL (Offices of plaintiff's attorneys)
New York, NY (Various law firm offices)
Salt Lake City, UT (Paul G. Cassell's office)
United States District Court, Southern District of Florida
West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
keyFacts: Maxwell's legal team argues the presumption of public access for discovery dispute documents is low, not high, citing the Second Circuit's decision in Brown.

The filing contends that unsealing deposition excerpts and other materials would lead to abuse, defamation, and violate the privacy interests of non-parties (referred to as Does) who relied on a protective order.
Maxwell's attorneys accuse plaintiff's counsel (Sigrid McCawley) of making misrepresentations to the court and the media, and of intending for sealed materials to be abused by the press.
The document reveals that some sealed materials contain highly personal questions asked of Maxwell about her private life, which her team argues are embarrassing and irrelevant.
The filing indicates there are numerous pending civil lawsuits and a referenced ongoing criminal investigation related to Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.

The court denied motions by two additional alleged victims (Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4) to join the existing CVRA lawsuit, finding their participation as named parties unnecessary for the case's merits.

The court struck 'lurid details' from the record, including Jane Doe 3's allegations of being trafficked by Epstein to 'prominent American politicians, powerful business executives, foreign presidents, a well-known Prime Minister, and other world leaders.'
Alan Dershowitz's motion to intervene to strike allegations against him was denied as moot because the court took it upon itself to strike the impertinent details.

The court ruled that Jane Doe 3 and Jane Doe 4 could participate as fact witnesses but did not need to be named parties, as the original petition already sought relief for 'similarly-situated victims.'
The government opposed the joinder, arguing undue delay and prejudice, and also contested whether Jane Doe 4 was a proper party entitled to CVRA rights.
